Wear a hat when you go outside. Too much sun exposure can damage your hair

You can use minoxidil, Minoxidil (Rogaine) is the only drug approved by the U. S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) to treat female pattern baldness

You can use Finasteride (Propecia, Proscar), a pill that interferes with the production of a highly active form of testosterone that is linked to baldness. It slows hair loss. It works slightly better than minoxidil. Hair loss returns when you stop using this medicine.

People typically lose 50 to 100 hairs a day. This usually isn't noticeable because new hair is growing in at the same time. Hair loss occurs when new hair doesn't replace the hair that has fallen out.

patterns: When should I see the doctor
responses: swelling around the areas of baldness
excessive itchiness or scaling around balding areas
burning, stinging, or pus discharge around balding areas
sudden hair loss on other parts of your body

patterns: What are the meaning of hair loss
responses: Hair loss, also called alopecia, can start at almost any age as you enter adulthood.
Baldness usually refers to excessive hair loss on the scalp. Hereditary hair loss with age is the most common cause of baldness.

patterns: How do people deal with baldness
How people deal with hair loss
responses: Some people prefer to let their hair loss run its course untreated and unhidden. Others may cover it up with hairstyles, makeup, hats or scarves. And still others choose one of the treatments available to prevent further hair loss or restore growth.

patterns: What are the symptoms of hair loss
What are the symptoms of baldness
responses: The symptoms of hair loss are gradual thinning on top of head, circular or patchy bald spots, patches of scaling that spread over the scalp.

patterns: What are the signs of hair loss
What are the signs of baldness
responses: The signs of hair loss are sudden loosening of hair and full-body hair loss.
You should talk with your doctor about early treatment to avoid significant permanent baldness.

patterns: What are the factors of baldness
responses: The factors include family history, hormonal changes and medical conditions, side effect of medications and supplements, radiation therapy to the head, stressful event, excessive hairstyling.

patterns: What will increase the risk of hair loss
responses: The risk factors include age, significant weight loss, certain medical conditions, such as diabetes and lupus, stress, poor nutrition.

patterns: What type of hair loss is not preventable
responses: Most baldness is caused by genetics (male-pattern baldness and female-pattern baldness). This type of hair loss is not preventable.

patterns: How to avoid preventable hair loss
responses: Avoid harsh treatments such as hot rollers, curling irons, hot-oil treatments and permanents.
Limit the tension on hair from styles that use rubber bands, barrettes and braids.
Protect your hair from sunlight and other sources of ultraviolet light.
Stop smoking. Some studies show an association between smoking and baldness in men.
Ask your doctor about medications and supplements you take that might cause hair loss.

patterns: What are surgical procedures to treat baldness.
responses: The surgical procedures include Hair Transplant Surgery or Scalp Reduction. These surgical remedies for baldness tend to be expensive, and they carry risks including bleeding, wide scars, infection, patchy hair growth.

patterns: What are the products that can affect hairloss
What are the tools that can affect hairloss
responses: The products and tools that will affect hair loss include blow dryers, heated combs, hair straighteners, colouring products, bleaching agents, relaxers, perms.

patterns: Which women are more likely to experience hair loss
responses: Women older than 40, women who have just had babies, women who often have hairstyles that pull on the hair and menopausal women are more likely to experience hair loss.

patterns: What are the myths about hair loss
What are the myths about baldness
responses: If you shave your head, your hair will grow back twice as thick.
You’re losing hair because you shampoo it too much, or because you’ve colored it or gotten a perm.
If you stand on your head you’ll increase circulation, stimulating hair growth.
If you brush your hair 100 strokes a day that will make your hair healthier.

patterns: What type of doctors treat hairloss
responses: A family physician, internist, or gynecologist can perform a basic health screening. Dermatologists are doctors who specialize in problems of skin, hair, and nails and may provide more advanced diagnosis and treatment of hair thinning and loss. Sometimes a scalp biopsy may be necessary

patterns: Can itchy scalp cause hair loss
responses: Itchy scalp may be a symptom of a scalp disease that could produce hair loss. Causes may include seborrheic dermatitis (dandruff) and psoriasis. Treatments may include medicated shampoos like ketoconazole (Nizoral), OTC dandruff shampoos, and topical steroid creams and lotions to help decrease itching.

patterns: At what age do men start losing hair?
Age of man start experience hair loss
responses: According to the American Hair Loss Association, approximately 25 percent of men who have hereditary male pattern baldness start losing their hair before the age of 21. By the age of 35, approximately 66 percent of men will have experienced some degree of hair loss. By the age of 50, approximately 85 percent of men will have significantly thinner hair.

patterns: Medications that may cause hair loss
responses: Medication associated with hair loss are chemotherapy drugs, acne medications such as isotretinoin, antifungal drugs, blood pressure medications, cholesterol-lowering drugs, antidepressants.

patterns: Does hair loss indicate health condition
responses: Yes. Hair loss can also indicate a health condition, such as lupus, a fungal infection, or a thyroid problem.

patterns: How much hair falling out is normal
responses: According to the American Academy of Dermatologists, it's normal to lose anywhere from 50 to 100 strands of hair per day.

patterns: What should we eat to reduce hair loss
responses: Type of food to reduce hair loss include fatty fish such as Tuna, Mackerel, Salmon, Herring have essential fatty acids, including omega-3s, and vitamin D. Eggs contain nutrients such as protein, biotin, selenium, and zinc. Leafy Greens such as Kale, Spinach, Collards contain vitamin A, iron, beta carotene, folate, and vitamin C. Fruits and nuts such as berries, grapes, oranges, walnuts, almonds, chia seeds.

Red meat, grass-fed, leafy greens and legumes are rich of iron.

patterns: What is the sympton of iron deficiency?
responses: Symptons include fatigue, pale skin and hair loss.

patterns: How to take more Vitamin C
Where can I get Vitamin C
What food rich of Vitamin C?
responses: You can get Vitamin C from citrus fruit, leafy greens and bell peppers.

patterns: How to take more Vitamin D
Where can I get Vitamin D
What food rich of Vitamin D?
responses: You can boost your levels of Vitamin D by eating fatty fish or drinkingf fortified milk. You can also ask your doctor to recommend a supplement.
You can get Vitamin C from shellfish, meat, beans, nuts and seeds.

context: Telogen effluvium (TE) is a common form of hair loss characterized by diffuse hair shedding, resulting from the early entry of the hair into the telogen phase.

patterns: What the factor or cause of telogen?
responses: factors include systemic diseases, stressful events, drugs, nutritional deficiencies and major surgery.
Hair loss occurs 3 months after the causing event and is usually self‐limiting, lasting for about 6 months.There is a delay because there are various phases of the hair cycle.

patterns: How many percentage in growing phase
responses: Usually around 85% are in the growing phase

patterns: How many percentage in resting phase and shedding?
responses: 5% resting and around 10% are shedding

patterns: How many percentage of baldness when stressful
responses: When a person has a major stress event or shock, up to 50% of their hair can be prematurely pushed into the shedding phase.
TE typically starts 2 to 4 months after the inciting event and can last up to 6 months.

patterns: What risk factors do patients who are experiencing telogen effluvium after COVID infection have?
responses: Experts say it is hard to know why some patients recovering from COVID lose hair and others do not. It may be related to genetics. We know that hair loss happens to people who are predisposed, but we do not know who or why. There are specifics about one’s hair cycle and genetics that make them prone or predisposed to developing TE.

patterns: What can be done to combat this issue?
responses: Time. The majority of TE cases resolve within 6 months. For those who want to speed up the process, topical minoxidil applied once daily can be helpful, as long as the patient is not pregnant or nursing.

patterns: What i need to eat to prevent TE
responses: Eat a well-balanced diet with adequate protein. A daily multivitamin can also help ensure the patient has the building blocks needed for optimal hair growth

patterns: What i need to do excercise to prevent TE
responses: Try to minimize stress by doing exercise, yoga or meditation.

patterns: How can i stop hair loss?
responses: Wondering how to stop hair loss before it goes any further? While there's no cure for male pattern baldness, minoxidil and finasteride provide two very safe and effective ways to help prevent further hair loss.

patterns: Is summer hair loss is real things?
responses: Yes, Although it may feel like your head is on fire after hours hanging out at the beach, sustained exposure to sunshine is not a direct cause of hair loss. However, Dr. Antonella Tosti, hair loss expert and Keeps medical advisor, notes that if you notice your hair getting lighter during the summer, it’s a sign of damage that’ll likely result in your hair becoming dry.

patterns: How dp prevent summer hair loss
responses: Just because that blazing hot sun doesn’t cause hair loss, doesn’t mean it’s good for you. Be sure to always apply SPF—it’s your skin’s best friend—and add a hat up top if you want some extra protection.

patterns: Is Chlorine and salt water leads to baldness?
responses: Although excess chlorine and salt water may dry out your hair for a few days, neither of these things cause hair to fall out. However, if you’re worried about the texture of your hair after spending time in the pool or ocean, check out these research-backed tips to get your hair back to peak health.

patterns: How do i prevent Chlorine and salt water make me hair loss
responses: Before and after swimming, condition your hair to maintain its moisture. Tosti recommends rinsing your hair with tap water to reduce how many chemicals (such as chlorine) are absorbed.

patterns: Why Genetics make my ahir falling down
responses: Genetics play the largest role in how susceptible you are to androgenetic alopecia (also known as male pattern baldness)

patterns: How can i make my hair grow faster?
responses: Growth speed is genetically determined, but nutrition from the inside is important. believe healthy and beautiful hair grows from a healthy scalp, and an essential oils scalp treatment can really help

patterns: What is the best way to prevent heat damage?
responses: Heat-protecting sprays are the best way to protect hair from damage

patterns: How often should I wash my hair?
responses: Every two-three days. Washing every day can strip hair of its natural oils

patterns: How often should I get my hair cut?
responses: Aim to get a trim or cut every month-and-a-half

patterns: What is the most effective way to reduce frizz?
responses: Invest in a good nourishing treatment. Let hair dry naturally, but if you use a hairdryer, avoid touching it with the nozzle as direct heat promotes frizziness.

Traditionally, conditioner is applied every time after shampooing and rinsing the hair. To use a conditioner, you need to wet your hair, lather the scalp with shampoo while massaging it gently into the scalp and then rinse out the product.

patterns: Why does the scalp get greasy often?
responses: Sometimes the hair becomes too greasy over a period of time because of the oils secreted from the scalp, some people produce more oils than others.

patterns: How Women's and Men's Hair Care Products Differ?
responses: two main characteristic features to mention are that male skin is thicker and ages slower.
Zinc can play a key role in making proteins in your hair and other cells

patterns: What happens if I take too much vitamins?
responses: Overdoing vitamins and nutritions supplements can cause baldness. Taking too much of vitamin A can also cause hair loss.
Excess in Selenium, Vitamin A, Zinc and Vitamin E will lead to hair loss.

patterns: Can hair grow back after balding?
responses: Spot baldness, or alopecia areata, makes your hair fall out in smooth, round patches, but it usually grows back.

patterns: What disease has the symptons of hair loss?
responses: Several health conditions, including thyroid disease and iron deficiency anemia, can cause hair loss.
If you are experiencing sudden or unexplained hair loss, it is best to visit a dermatologist.

patterns: What phases are there in hair growth?
How many phases are there in hair growth?
responses: Human hair naturally grows in three phases: anagen, catagen, and telogen. Anagen is the active or growing phase. Catagen is a fairly short phase of the natural hair cycle during which hairs begin to break down. Telogen is the resting phase. The hairs that are shed daily are often in the resting or late phase in the hair cycle.

patterns: Does tight hairstyle lead to baldness?
responses: Tight hairstyle lead to traction alopecia. Traction alopecia refers to a small or localized hair loss area caused by repetitive or persistent pulling or force on hair roots.
Under normal conditions, scalp hairs live for about three years. This period is referred to as the anagen, or growing, phase. They subsequently enter the telogen, or resting, phase.
Shampooing does not accelerate hair loss; it just removes the hairs that were ready to fall out anyway.

patterns: Does hair coloring lead to baldness?
responses: Coloring, perming, and conditioning the hair do not usually cause hair loss. Burns or severe processing may cause hair loss and breakage.
